Vision on Wheels
One summer day... my dad came home in a vehicle I didn’t recognize.
I asked my dad, "Did you get a job as a bread delivery guy? Am I going to have to deliver bread?"
<div>
Dad always took on extra work, since he didn't make a ton of money as a teacher.
More often than not, I had to help and I thought this was another side job.

I could not believe this.

THERE WAS NO WAY!!!
<div class='shadow-box-white'>
I thought his idea was CRAZY! But my dad, he had vision. He could see how it would turn out before we even got started.
<div>
This was my first introduction to engineering. My dad saw the bread truck and it was like a puzzle for him. He could
imagine a practical way to make the truck into something better.
We had access to all the pieces and he knew how to put them all together to make them work. He could envision it all.
He shared his vision with me. There would be a set of bunk beds for me and my sister.
A pullout couch where my parents would sleep.
There was even enough space for a small camping stove and a corner where we could tuck in a little table.
<div>
I still couldn’t see his vision.
Once we got into the work of it, though, it was like the layers of his vision started to show through for me.
Over the summer, as we built the bunks together, ran the propane line to the stove, and installed the couch, the vision became more real.
When we finally painted over the Merita bread sign, my dad’s vision—the thing he had imagined
when he saw that old bread truck for sale—was now complete.
It wasn’t the most beautiful thing in the world, but it had everything we needed.
I learned something working with my dad. He taught me how to use my imagination. He taught me how to design
and build what I envisioned—that vision means you look beyond the here and now.
Thanks dad!
